node.title: Former Canberra football coach sends himself to jail for child sex abuse
node.alt: A man in a suit and wearing a mask, walking in front of a court building.
node.description: Stephen Porter asked theÂ ACT Supreme Court to send him to jail immediately, even though he hasn't yet been sentenced for his child abuse crimes.
node.content: ["A former Ainslie Football Club coach who committed sexual offences against three boys has sent himself to jail.", "Stephen James Porter, 51, pleaded guilty to the offences but is disputing some aspects of the charges.", "He was initially charged with multiple offences and pleaded\u00a0guilty to three of them earlier this year.", "They included grooming a child, using a child to create child exploitation material, and maintaining a sexual relationship with a child under 12.", "His offending took place\u00a0between 2015 and 2018.", "The court is yet to rule on his version of the incidents, and he is not due to be sentenced until February.", "In the meantime, he has been free in the community on bail.", "But on Monday\u00a0he formally asked the ACT Supreme Court to send him to prison so he could start the clock on his sentence, saying\u00a0he believed he would be spending time in jail.", "Justice Chrissa Loukas Karlson agreed, saying revoking his bail was the right decision.", "\"Revoking his bail is the right thing to do.\"", "Two Corrections officers took Porter away.", "The charge of maintaining a sexual relationship with a child carries a maximum penalty of 25 years in the ACT\u00a0if it involves more than one act.", "Although Porter has pleaded guilty, he is still disputing details of his offences against one of the boys.", "In earlier hearings,\u00a0that boy described to the court how Porter groomed and molested him after he began doing Australian rules football training with him.", "Porter has disputed some of the boy's allegations."]
